title: How to Eat a Plantain

steps.headline: Select a plantain that is black with a bit of yellow if you want it ripe.
steps.description: Ripe plantains are ideal for baking whole plantains or frying larger pieces. If you're going to eat a ripe plantain, try to select one that is mostly black with just a bit of yellow. If you have a completely black plantain, baking it whole is your best bet—cutting it is much more difficult because of how soft it is. Squeeze your plantain for a second ripeness check—if it's slightly firm like a peach, you're good to go! If your plantain isn't ripe, let it sit for 3 days to 1 week. Check Latin or Asian markets if you want to purchase ripe plantains.

steps.headline: Find a green plantain if you want it unripe.
steps.description: Unripe plantains are more firm, which makes them ideal for cutting into thin pieces for chips. If you're going to eat an unripe plantain, look for one that's completely green or almost completely green. Check any grocery store for unripe plantains—they're easier to find than ripe ones.

steps.headline: Remove the ends of the plantain with a knife.
steps.description: Place the plantain horizontally onto a cutting board. Hold the middle with your non-dominant hand and remove each end from the plantain with a sharp knife—about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) from each side is ideal. A paring knife works best for cutting plantains, but you can use any kind of sharp kitchen knife as well.

steps.headline: Score the 4 seams along the peel of the plantain.
steps.description: Keep the plantain horizontally in front of you and continue holding it with your non-dominant hand. Start with each seam facing toward you and cut down each one horizontally from left to right or right to left. Try not to cut far enough through the plantain that you score the flesh.

steps.headline: Pry a slice of peel from the plantain.
steps.description: After scoring the 4 seams of the peel, insert your paring knife horizontally into one of the cut lines until about 1 inch (2.5 cm) of it is underneath the peel. Now, push downward on the handle to pry the peel up and remove it from the plantain. Take care not to cut the plantain as you remove the peel.

steps.headline: Remove the remaining 3 pieces of peel.
steps.description: Grab the piece of peel directly above the exposed plantain and run your fingers under it to peel it off. Continue doing this for the other 2 pieces. Don't use your nails to peel off plantain peel—this will really hurt your skin! Pry the peel off with a paring knife if you're having trouble using your fingers.

steps.headline: Slice each of your unripe plantains into thin slices with a mandolin slicer.
steps.description: Place the blade of the mandolin slicer perpendicular in front of you. Cut your plantain in half and place the rounded end into the hand pusher. Now, slide the flat side of the plantain across the blades using even strokes and consistent pressure. Make sure the slices are less than ⁄16 inch (0.16 cm) thick. Repeat this process with the second half of the plantain. Adjust the thickness of each cut with the knob or lever on the side of the slicer. If you don't have a mandolin slicer, cut slices with your paring knife. Hold each plantain vertically in place and cut perpendicular into the end of the plantain to make small, circular slices.

steps.headline: Heat 1 inch (2.5 cm) of oil to 375 °F (191 °C).
steps.description: Fill a measuring cup with 4 cups (950 mL) of oil. Now, start pouring the oil into a 1 to 1.25 gallon (3.8 to 4.7 L) pot until it's 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the bottom. Afterward, set one of your elements to 375 °F (191 °C) and wait. If your element doesn't let you set a specific temperature, turn the knob to medium-high, or between 5 and 7.

steps.headline: Fry your plantain slices for 3 minutes in small batches.
steps.description: Gently drop your slices into the oil—each one should sizzle upon contact. Cook them in small batches and give them enough space between each other. In addition, make sure there's only one layer of plantains frying at a time. Cook each batch for around 3 minutes or until they are crispy and golden. If your slices don't sizzle after hitting the oil, wait for the oil to heat for a few more minutes.

steps.headline: Remove your plantain chips and dry them on paper towel.
steps.description: Use a frying basket or slotted spoon to remove your plantains. Place them on a piece of paper towel over a plate and wait for them to drain. Afterward, pour them into a bowl and enjoy! Sprinkle some salt onto your plantain chips if you'd like. Store your plantain chips at room temperature in an airtight container for up to 1 day.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.description: If your oven is electric, you'll have to wait about 10 to 15 minutes for your oven to heat. For gas ovens, you'll need to wait just 5 to 10 minutes. Place the oven rack in the middle position. Use an oven thermometer to track temperature for increased accuracy.

steps.headline: Apply cooking spray or olive oil to a baking sheet with foil.
steps.description: Place a piece of aluminum foil over your baking sheet and press it down firmly. If you're using cooking spray, apply a light coat across the entire surface of the foil. For olive oil, apply 1 tablespoon (15 mL) and then spread it across the surface of the sheet with a paper towel. If it doesn't cover the whole surface, apply more until it does. Wrap the edges of the aluminum foil over the baking sheet to help it stay in place.

steps.headline: Bake your plantains for 30 minutes until they're tender and golden brown.
steps.description: Place all of your plantain pieces onto the aluminum foil. Afterward, lightly spray the top of them with cooking spray and then place them into the middle oven rack. Wait about 15 minutes and then turn them over. After another 15 minutes, they should be done! If the plantains aren't tender and golden brown after 30 minutes, keep baking in 5-minute intervals until they are.

steps.headline: Serve your baked plantains with your choice of toppings.
steps.description: Baked plantains go great with plenty of different toppings, such as cheese, guacamole, beans, peppers, and/or cilantro. You can also cut them down the middle and stuff them with the same ingredients. If you like to keep it simple, eat them plain! Spray whipped cream on top of your plantains for a nice dessert. Cut your plantains in half to make them easier to eat. You can also leave them whole and use a fork and knife to eat them piece by piece!

steps.headline: Slice 2 plantains into ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick pieces.
steps.description: Place each plantain horizontally onto a cutting board. Hold each one gently with your non-dominant hand and slice them into coins approximately ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick. Cut each piece into a diagonal angle if that's easier for you.

steps.headline: Pour ⁄16 inch (0.16 cm) of olive oil into a large frying pan.
steps.description: Fill a measuring cup with ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of olive oil. Now, gently pour the oil into your frying pan until there is a thin ⁄16 inch (0.16 cm) layer coating the bottom. Swap olive oil with avocado or coconut oil for other healthy alternatives.

steps.headline: Heat the oil on medium heat or 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Place your pan onto the closest stove element and set its temperature to medium. For ovens that let you set exact temperature, set the element temperature to 350 °F (177 °C). Continue heating the oil until it starts to simmer across the pan. Simmering can be spotted by a small bubble or two popping through the oil's surface every 1 to 2 seconds.

steps.headline: Fry your plantains for 2.5 to 3 minutes or until they're brown and crispy.
steps.description: Start placing your plantains into the oil, making sure there is only a single layer and a bit of space between each. Let them fry for about 1.5 to 2 minutes on one side and then use tongs or a spatula to flip them over. Now, wait for another 1 minute until they are medium-brown colored and crispy on both sides. If you can't fit all of your plantains into your pan, fry them in batches. Flip your plantain batches at the same time to ensure an even heating time.

steps.headline: Blot your plantains on paper towels and serve.
steps.description: Place your plantains onto a plate lined with a paper towel to blot them dry by absorbing excess oil. Give them 5 to 10 minutes to cool before serving them with your choice of pepper, sea salt, and spices to taste. Serve your plantains on top of salads, with spicy meats, or mixed with whipped cream and/or honey as a sweet snack. Eat your fried plantains immediately after frying them.
